text.p: Following are the main stories in Slovenia's Wednesday morning newspapers:
- Five members of the Slovenian mountain rescue service died during a rescue exercise in the Slovenian Alps on Tuesday.
- Parliamentary parties have not yet reached an agreement on changing the constitution in order to enable foreigners to buy land in Slovenia in line with European Union rules.

- Work unions and management of state-owned Slovenian Railways reached an agreement on salaries but unions said they would start another strike on Friday if the government fails to approve the agreement on Thursday. Their previous 11-day strike ended on May 31.
- The European Commission said it would let the EU hopefuls, among them Slovenia, know of their chances of joining the EU in mid-July.
- Slovenia's union of custom officials said they may start a stike next week because of irregular payments for extra work hours and irregularities regarding promotions.

- The parliamentary board for election prepared a proposal for a new parliamentary constitutional committee, which would prepare the necessary constitutional changes in line with the association agreement with the EU. The committee would consist of members of all parliamentary parties.

- The government's Office of Macroeconomic Analysis and Development in its latest report said the 1997 GDP growth is expected to reach four percent, up from 3.1 in 1996, unchanged from its previous forecasts.
- Bank Probanka said its 1997 balance sheet assets were expected to grow to 27.4 billion tolars ($176 million) from 22.4 billion in 1996.
